description: Find out if someone can rent your private residential property in England.

details.body:
You must check anyone aged 18 or over who pays to use your property as their main home, for example, tenants, sub-tenants and paying house guests.

Use this service to find out:

  • which types of documents give someone the right to rent in the UK
  • how to check someone’s documents

You might get a fine (‘civil penalty’) if you rent your property to someone who does not have the right to rent.

If you’ve bought a property that already has tenants, you need proof that their last landlord did the check. You’ll still be responsible for carrying out further checks on your tenants in future.

nodes.title: Is the property you want to let in England?

nodes.body:
A property would usually be a tenant’s only or main home if:

  • they live there most of the time
  • they keep most of their belongings there
  • their partner or children live with them
  • they’re registered to vote at the property
  • they’re registered with the doctor using that address
nodes.title: Is the person renting the property as their main home?

options.label: Accommodation to an employee or as part of training (for example, tied accommodation)
Student accommodation (student halls or where an arrangement has been made with the educational institution)
A residential property with a lease for 7 years or more
Another type of property (including mobile homes)

nodes.title: What kind of property are you letting?
Is the person at least 18 years old?

options.label: Citizen from the EU, Switzerland, Norway, Iceland or Liechtenstein
Citizen from Australia, Canada, Japan, New Zealand, Singapore, South Korea or USA

nodes.title: What is the person’s nationality?

nodes.body:
• a British passport (current or expired)
  • an Irish passport or passport card (current or expired)
  • a certificate of naturalisation or registration as a British citizen
nodes.title: Does the person have any of the following documents?

nodes.body:
• a current UK driving licence (full or provisional)
  • a full birth or adoption certificate from the UK, Guernsey, Jersey, the Isle of Man or Ireland (listing at least one birth or adoptive parent)
  • a letter from their employer giving their National Insurance or employee number and the employer’s name, signature and company address (dated within the past 3 months)
  • a letter confirming they’re enrolled to study, the course name and how long it lasts (from a UK further or higher education institution, dated within the past 3 months)
  • benefits paperwork from HMRC, a local authority, the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) or Jobcentre Plus (dated within the past 3 months)
  • a Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) certificate from a criminal records check (dated within the past 3 months)
  • evidence the person is currently serving in the UK armed forces or has previously served
  • a letter from a private rented sector access scheme, confirming the address of the property it’s helping the person rent from you (dated within the past 3 months)
  • a letter from a British passport holder in an accepted profession who’s known them for at least 3 months, with the professional’s name, address, signature, passport number, profession, most recent work address, how long they’ve known the person and in what capacity (dated within the past 3 months)
  • a letter confirming they’re known to a UK government department or local authority, with the signature and work address of a named official (dated within the past 3 months)
  • a letter from the UK police confirming that their passport or biometric residence permit was stolen, with the crime reference number (dated within the past 3 months)
  • a letter confirming they’ve been released from prison within the past 6 months, with their date of birth (from HM, Scottish or Northern Ireland Prison Service)
  • a letter confirming they’re on probation, from their offender manager (dated within the past 3 months)
nodes.title: Does the person have 2 of the following documents?
Does the person have settled or pre-settled status, or have they ever applied to the EU Settlement Scheme?

nodes.body: The person has:

options.label: settled status under the EU Settlement Scheme
pre-settled status under the EU Settlement Scheme
applied to the EU Settlement Scheme and is waiting for a decision
applied to the EU Settlement Scheme, but their application has been refused

nodes.title: Which of the following applies to this person?

options.label: the UK (England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland)
Guernsey, Jersey or the Isle of Man

nodes.title: Where did the person get their settled status?

options.label: the UK (England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland)
Guernsey, Jersey or the Isle of Man

nodes.title: Where did the person get their pre-settled status?
When did the tenant apply to the EU Settlement Scheme?
Does the person have a UK ‘certificate of entitlement to the right of abode’ (in their current or expired foreign passport)?

nodes.body:
The biometric residence card or permit must be:

  • current (not expired)
  • in the person’s name
  • issued by the Home Office
  • marked to show the person has limited leave to enter or remain in the UK
nodes.title: Does the person have a current biometric residence card or permit endorsed to show they’re allowed to stay in the UK for a limited time?

nodes.body:
The biometric residence card or permit must be:

  • current (not expired)
  • in the person’s name
  • issued by the Home Office
  • marked to show the person has indefinite leave to enter or remain in the UK
nodes.title: Does the person have a current biometric residence card or permit endorsed to show they’re allowed to stay in the UK indefinitely?

nodes.body:
This can be any of the following:

  • a ‘certificate of entitlement’ in their foreign passport
  • a ‘travel document’ or ‘immigration status document’
  • an ‘exempt vignette’ (sticker in their foreign passport) - it could also be marked

The document should be current, in the person’s name, and needs to show that the person has one of the following:

  • indefinite leave to enter or remain in the UK
  • no time limit to their stay in the UK
  • a certificate of entitlement to the Right of Abode
  • exemption from immigration control
nodes.title: Does the person have a Home Office document endorsed to show they’re allowed to stay indefinitely in the UK?

nodes.body:
This can be any of the following:

  • a sticker or stamp in their passport (called a ‘vignette’)
  • a ‘travel document’ or ‘immigration status document’

The endorsement should be current, in the person’s name and needs to show that the person has either:

  • limited leave to enter or remain in the UK
  • exemption from immigration control
nodes.title: Does the person have a passport or travel document endorsed to show they’re allowed to stay in the UK for a limited time?

nodes.body:
• the Home Office to return their documents
  • a decision on their immigration case or visa application
  • a decision on their immigration appeal or administrative review
nodes.title: If the person does not have the right documents, are they waiting for:
Did the Home Office tell the person they have permission to rent?

nodes.body:
The biometric residence card or permit must be:

  • current (not expired)
  • in the person’s name
  • issued by the Home Office
  • marked to show the person has limited leave to enter or remain in the UK
nodes.title: Does the person have a current biometric residence card or permit endorsed to show they’re allowed to stay in the UK for a limited time?

nodes.body:
The biometric residence card or permit must be:

  • current (not expired)
  • in the person’s name
  • issued by the Home Office
  • marked to show the person has indefinite leave to enter or remain in the UK

nodes.body:
This can be any of the following:

  • a sticker or stamp in their passport (called a ‘vignette’)
  • a ‘travel document’ or ‘immigration status document’

The endorsement should be current, in the person’s name and needs to show that the person has either:

  • limited leave to enter or remain in the UK
  • exemption from immigration control
nodes.title: Does the person have a passport or travel document endorsed to show they’re allowed to stay in the UK for a limited time?

nodes.body:
This can be any of the following:

  • a ‘certificate of entitlement’ in their foreign passport
  • a ‘travel document’ or ‘immigration status document’
  • an ‘exempt vignette’ (sticker in their foreign passport) - it could also be marked

The document should be current, in the person’s name, and needs to show that the person has one of the following:

  • indefinite leave to enter or remain in the UK
  • no time limit to their stay in the UK
  • a certificate of entitlement to the Right of Abode
  • exemption from immigration control
nodes.title: Does the person have a Home Office document endorsed to show they’re allowed to stay indefinitely in the UK?
Does the person have a current Frontier Worker permit?
Does the person have a current Service providers of Switzerland visa?
Is the person currently appealing their decision to the EU Settlement Scheme?

nodes.body:
The biometric residence card or permit must be:

  • current (not expired)
  • in the person’s name
  • issued by the Home Office
  • marked to show the person has limited leave to enter or remain in the UK
nodes.title: Does the person have a current biometric residence card or permit endorsed to show they’re allowed to stay in the UK for a limited time?

nodes.body:
The biometric residence card or permit must be:

  • current (not expired)
  • in the person’s name
  • issued by the Home Office
  • marked to show the person has indefinite leave to enter or remain in the UK

nodes.body:
This can be any of the following:

  • a sticker or stamp in their passport (called a ‘vignette’)
  • a ‘travel document’ or ‘immigration status document’

The endorsement should be current, in the person’s name and needs to show that the person has either:

  • limited leave to enter or remain in the UK
  • exemption from immigration control

nodes.body:
This can be any of the following:

  • a ‘certificate of entitlement’ in their foreign passport
  • a ‘travel document’ or ‘immigration status document’
  • an ‘exempt vignette’ (sticker in their foreign passport) - it could also be marked

The document should be current, in the person’s name, and needs to show that the person has one of the following:

  • indefinite leave to enter or remain in the UK
  • no time limit to their stay in the UK
  • a certificate of entitlement to the Right of Abode
  • exemption from immigration control
nodes.title: Does the person have a Home Office document endorsed to show they’re allowed to stay indefinitely in the UK?
Does the person have a current Frontier Worker permit?
Does the person have a current Service providers of Switzerland visa?
Does the person have a UK ‘certificate of entitlement to the right of abode’ (in their current or expired foreign passport)?
Does the person have a current biometric residence card or permit endorsed to show they’re allowed to stay in the UK for a limited time?
Does the person have a current biometric residence card or permit endorsed to show they’re allowed to stay in the UK indefinitely?
Does the person have a Home Office document endorsed to show they’re allowed to stay indefinitely in the UK?
Does the person have a passport or travel document endorsed to show they’re allowed to stay in the UK for a limited time?

nodes.body:
• the Home Office to return their documents
  • a decision on their immigration case or visa application
  • a decision on their immigration appeal or administrative review
nodes.title: If the person does not have the right documents, are they waiting for:
Did the Home Office tell the person they have permission to rent?

nodes.body:
You do not need to check a tenant’s right to rent property in Wales, Scotland or Northern Ireland.

You can read the landlord’s code of practice for more information.
nodes.title: You only need to do a right to rent check in England

nodes.body: You can read the landlord’s code of practice for more information.
nodes.title: You do not need to do a right to rent check

nodes.body:
You do not need to make a check if the hostel or refuge is:

  • managed by a social landlord, voluntary organisation or charity
  • not operated as a commercial basis
  • partly or wholly funded by a government department, agency or local authority

You’ll have to carry out a check in all other cases.

You can read the landlord’s code of practice for more information.
nodes.title: You might need to do a right to rent check

nodes.body:
You do not need to make a check for holiday accommodation if both of the following apply:

  • you’re letting the property for holiday or leisure
  • you’re letting the property to the person for under 3 months

You’ll have to do a check if:

  • you’re letting the property to the same person for longer than 3 months
  • the booking for the property is open-ended
  • you’ve extended the time the person has booked the property more than once

You can read the landlord’s code of practice for more information.
nodes.title: You might need to do a right to rent check

nodes.body:
You do not have to make a check if the student is in:

  • a halls of residence
  • any accommodation provided by their educational institution
  • any private accommodation agreed between the educational institution and the landlord

You’ll have to carry out a check in all other cases.

You can read the landlord’s code of practice for more information.
nodes.title: You might need to do a right to rent check

nodes.body:
You only have to do a right to rent check if there’s a break clause within the lease.

You can read the landlord’s code of practice for more information.
nodes.title: You might need to do a right to rent check

nodes.body:
You do not have to make a check if the tenant is under 18 years old.

You can read the landlord’s code of practice for more information.
nodes.title: You do not need to do a right to rent check

nodes.body:
You need to make a copy of the relevant parts of the documents and keep the copies for 12 months after the tenancy has ended.

You might get a fine (‘civil penalty’) if you cannot prove you’ve carried out the check.

You do not have to do this check again.

You can read the landlord’s code of practice for more information.
nodes.title: This person can rent the property

nodes.body:
This person cannot rent your property because they have not shown you documents to prove their right to rent.

If you think they do have the right to rent, check the full list of documents they can show you as proof.

If the person is already renting your property, you must report them to the Home Office. You do not need to evict them.

You can read the landlord’s code of practice for more information.
nodes.title: This person cannot rent your property

nodes.body:
You must view the tenant’s right to rent details online. You’ll need their share code.

Ask your tenant for their share code.

The tenant can get their share code by proving their right to rent online.

If the tenant does not give you their share code, use the Landlord Checking Service.

Find out more about using the Landlord Checking Service.

You might get a fine (‘civil penalty’) if you cannot prove you’ve carried out the check.

You do not have to do this check again.

You can read the landlord’s code of practice for more information.
nodes.title: This person can rent the property

nodes.body:
The tenant must show you a letter or email confirming they have settled status that was given in Guernsey, Jersey or the Isle of Man.

If they’re from Jersey, they’ll need to use the online immigration status checker to get a confirmation letter.

You must then use the Landlord Checking Service to find out if the tenant is allowed to rent a property.

Using the Landlord Checking Service

You’ll need the person’s Home Office reference number and date of birth to use the service.

You should get an answer within 2 working days.

Find out more about using the Landlord Checking Service.

If the tenant is allowed to rent your property

You need to make a copy of both:

  • the letter or email confirming they have settled or status
  • the response from the Landlord Checking Service - this is called a Positive Right to Rent Notice (PRRN)

You might get a fine (‘civil penalty’) if you cannot prove you’ve carried out the check.

You do not need to do this check again.

You can read the landlord’s code of practice for more information.
nodes.title: This person can rent the property if they can prove their settled status

nodes.body:
You must view the tenant’s right to rent details online. You’ll need their share code.

Ask your tenant for their share code.

The tenant can get their share code by proving their right to rent online.

If the tenant does not give you their share code, use the Landlord Checking Service.

Find out more about using the Landlord Checking Service.

Follow-up checks

Do the follow-up check just before the date that’s the later of:

  • the end of your tenant’s permission to stay in the UK
  • 12 months after your previous check

Report your tenant to the Home Office if you check again and find that one of the following is true:

  • the tenant’s pre-settled status has expired and has not been renewed
  • the tenant has not switched to settled status

You might get a fine (‘civil penalty’) if you cannot prove you’ve carried out the check.

You can read the landlord’s code of practice for more information.
nodes.title: This person can rent the property if they can prove their pre-settled status

nodes.body:
How you check this person’s right to rent depends on whether they have a digital Certificate of Application.

You might get a penalty if you cannot prove you’ve carried out the check.

If they have a digital Certificate of Application

They can prove their right to rent online and give you their ‘share code’. You’ll need to use their share code to view the tenant’s right to rent details online.

The tenant can view their digital Certificate of Application online using the View and prove your immigration status service. It is an electronic record, not an email or physical document.

You must make a copy of their Certificate of Application and keep it for 12 months after the tenancy has ended.

If they do not have a digital Certificate of Application

You can use the Landlord Checking Service to check the tenant’s right to rent if they have one of the following:

  • a non-digital Certificate of Application - this could be a letter or an email confirming their rights
  • an email or letter confirmation of their application to the EU Settlement Scheme (EUSS)

Using the Landlord Checking Service

You’ll need the person’s Home Office reference number and date of birth to use the service.

You should get an answer within 2 working days.

Find out more about using the Landlord Checking Service.

If the tenant is allowed to rent your property

You must make a copy of:

  • either their Certificate of Application or their confirmation of application to the EUSS
  • the response from the Landlord Checking Service - this is called a Positive Right to Rent Notice (PRRN)

You must keep the copies for 12 months after the tenancy has ended.

You can read the landlord’s code of practice for more information.
nodes.title: This person might be able to rent your property

nodes.body:
You’ll need to check your tenant’s original documents.

Check the full list of documents your tenant can show you as proof.

Check the steps you need to take when checking original documents.

You need to make a copy of the relevant parts of the documents.

Follow-up checks

Do the follow-up check just before the date that’s the later of:

  • the end of your tenant’s permission to stay in the UK
  • 12 months after your previous check

Report your tenant to the Home Office if you check again and find out the tenant does not have the right to rent your property.

You might get a fine (‘civil penalty’) if you cannot prove you’ve carried out the check.

You can read the landlord’s code of practice for more information.
nodes.title: This person can rent the property

nodes.body:
You can either:

  • check your tenant’s original documents
  • view your tenant’s right to rent online if they have a ‘share code’

You might get a fine (‘civil penalty’) if you cannot prove you’ve carried out the check.

How to check original documents

You must ask the tenant to give you their original documents.

You must check that:

  • the photograph and date of birth are the same across the tenants documents
  • the photograph on the document is a photograph of the tenant
  • the endorsement to show the tenant is allowed to stay in the UK for a limited time has not expired

If the tenant has a different name to the name on their documents, you must ask the tenant to provide supporting documents. Supporting documents can include:

  • a marriage certificate
  • a deed poll
  • a decree

You must be with the tenant in person or on a video call when you do the check.

You need to make a copy of the relevant parts of the documents and keep the copies for 12 months after the tenancy has ended.

How to check with a share code

Check the person’s right to rent online, if they’ve given you their share code.

The tenant can get their share code by proving their right to rent online.

If your tenant can prove their right to rent using an original document, you cannot make them use the online service instead.

You do not have to do this check again.

You can read the landlord’s code of practice for more information.
nodes.title: This person can rent the property

nodes.body:
You can use the Landlord Checking Service to check the tenant’s right to rent if they have a Certificate of Application.

You might get a fine (‘civil penalty’) if you cannot prove you’ve carried out the check.

Using the Landlord Checking Service

You’ll need the person’s Home Office reference number and date of birth to use the service.

You should an answer within 2 working days.

Find out more about using the Landlord Checking Service.

If the tenant is allowed to rent your property

You must make a copy of both:

  • their Certificate of Application
  • the response from the Landlord Checking Service - this is called a Positive Right to Rent Notice (PRRN)

You must keep the copies for 12 months after the tenancy has ended.

You can read the landlord’s code of practice for more information.
nodes.title: You need to use the Landlord Checking Service to check the tenant's right to rent

nodes.body:
You must use the Landlord Checking Service to check the tenant’s right to rent.

You might get a fine (‘civil penalty’) if you cannot prove you’ve carried out the check.

Using the Landlord Checking Service

You’ll need the person’s Home Office reference number and date of birth to use the service.

You should get an answer within 2 working days.

Find out more about using the Landlord Checking Service.

If the tenant is allowed to rent your property

You must make a copy of the response from the Landlord Checking Service - this is called a Positive Right to Rent Notice (PRRN).

You must keep the copy for 12 months after the tenancy has ended.

The Home Office will tell you if you need to check their documents again later.

You can read the landlord’s code of practice for more information.
nodes.title: You need to use the Landlord Checking Service to check the tenant's right to rent

nodes.body:
The tenant must show you a letter or email confirming they have pre-settled status that was given in Guernsey, Jersey or the Isle of Man.

If they’re from Jersey, they’ll need to use the online immigration status checker to get a confirmation letter.

You must then use the Landlord Checking Service to check if the tenant is allowed to rent property.

You’ll need the person’s Home Office reference number and date of birth to use the service.

You should get an answer within 2 working days.

Find out more about using the Landlord Checking Service.

If the tenant is allowed to rent your property

You need to make a copy of both:

  • the letter or email confirming they have pre-settled status
  • the response from the Landlord Checking Service - this is called a Positive Right to Rent Notice (PRRN)

Follow-up checks

Do the follow-up check just before the date that’s the later of:

  • the end of your tenant’s permission to stay in the UK
  • 12 months after your previous check

Report your tenant to the Home Office if you check again and find that one of the following is true:

  • the tenant’s pre-settled status has expired and has not been renewed
  • the tenant has not switched to settled status

You might get a fine (‘civil penalty’) if you cannot prove you’ve carried out the check.

You can read the landlord’s code of practice for more information.
nodes.title: This person can rent the property if they can prove their pre-settled status

nodes.body:
You must view the tenant’s right to rent details online. You’ll need their share code.

Ask your tenant for their share code.

The tenant can get their share code by proving their right to rent online.

If the tenant does not give you their share code, use the Landlord Checking Service.

Find out more about using the Landlord Checking Service.

Follow-up checks

Do the follow-up check just before the date that’s the later of:

  • the end of your tenant’s permission to stay in the UK
  • 12 months after your previous check

Report your tenant to the Home Office if you check and find out the tenant does not have the right to rent your property.

You might get a fine (‘civil penalty’) if you cannot prove you’ve carried out the check.

You can read the landlord’s code of practice for more information.
nodes.title: This person can rent the property

nodes.body:
You can either:

  • check your tenant’s original documents
  • view your tenant’s right to rent online if they have a ‘share code’

How to check original documents

You must ask the tenant to give you their original documents.

You must check that:

the photograph and date of birth are the same across the tenants documents the photograph on the document is a photograph of the tenant the endorsement to show the tenant is allowed to stay in the UK for a limited time has not expired

If the tenant has a different name to the name on their documents, you must ask the tenant to provide supporting documents. Supporting documents can include:

  • a marriage certificate
  • a deed poll
  • a decree

You must be with the tenant in person or on a video call when you do the check.

You need to make a copy of the relevant parts of the documents and keep the copies for 12 months after the tenancy has ended.

How to check with a share code

Check the person’s right to rent online, if they’ve given you their share code.

The tenant can get their share code by proving their right to rent online.

If your tenant can prove their right to rent using an original document, you cannot make them use the online service instead.

Follow-up checks

Do the follow-up check just before the date that’s the later of:

  • the end of your tenant’s permission to stay in the UK
  • 12 months after your previous check

Report your tenant to the Home Office if you check and find out the tenant does not have the right to rent your property.

You might get a fine (‘civil penalty’) if you cannot prove you’ve carried out the check.

You can read the landlord’s code of practice for more information.
nodes.title: This person can rent the property

nodes.body:
You do not need to do a check if the tenant is not renting the property as their main home.

You can read the landlord’s code of practice for more information.
nodes.title: You do not need to do a right to rent check

nodes.body:
This person can rent your property if they:

  • are visiting the UK for 6 months or less
  • have proof they arrived in the UK in the last 6 months

How to check their documents

You need to check their passport showing they’re from one of the following countries:

  • an EU country
  • Australia
  • Canada
  • Iceland
  • Japan
  • Liechtenstein
  • New Zealand
  • Norway
  • Singapore
  • South Korea
  • Switzerland
  • USA

They must give you a document that includes the date they arrived in the UK, such as:

  • a boarding pass
  • a travel ticket
  • their booking confirmation

The date they arrived in the UK must be in the last 6 months.

They can give you an original or copy of the document. It can be an electronic or physical version.

You must have their passport and documents with you when you check them with the tenant in person or on a video call. The tenant cannot show the documents to you on screen.

You’ll then need to make a copy of the relevant parts of the documents.

You can read the landlord’s code of practice for more information.
nodes.title: This person might be able to rent the property

available_translations.title: Check if someone can rent your residential property

title: Check if someone can rent your residential property
